titleStmt.title:
A Character, Panegyric & Description of
The Legion Club.

publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: As I strole the City, oft I
See a Building large & lofty,
Not a Bowshot from the College,
Half the Globe from sense & Knowledge,
By the prudent Architect
Plac'd against the Church direct,
Making good my Grandame's Iest,
Near the Church── you know the rest.
Tell us what the Pile contains,
Many a Head that holds no Brains;
These Dæmoniacs let me dubb
With the name of Legion Clubb.
Such Assemblies you might swear,
Meet when Butchers beat a Bear;
Such a Noise & such Haranguing
When a Brother Thief is hanging;
Such a Rout & such a Rabble
Run to hear Iack-Pudding gabble.
Such a Crowd their Ordure throws
On a far less Villains nose.
Coud I from the Building top
Hear the rattling Thunder drop,
While the Devil upon the Roof
(If the Devil be Thunder proof)
Shoud with Poker fiery red
Crack the Stones & melt the Lead,
Drive 'em down on ev'ry Scull,
While the Den of Thieves is full,
Quite destroy the Harpies nest;
How might then our Isle be blessd:
For Divines allow that God
Sometimes makes the Devil his rod,
And the Gospel will inform us
He can punish Sins enormous.
Yet shoud Swift endow the Schools
For his Lunatics & Fools
With a Rood or two of Land
I allow the Pile may the stand.
You perhaps will ask me why so,
But it is with this Proviso;
Since the House is like to last
Let a Royal Grant be passd,
Let the Club have right to dwell
Each within his proper Cell;
With a Passage left to creep in
And a Hole above for peeping,
Let them when they once get in
Sell the Nation for a Pin;
While they sit a picking Straws
Let them rave of making Laws,
While they never hold their tongue
Let them dabble in their Dung.
Let them form a Grand Committee
How to plague & starve the City.
Let them stare & storm & frown
When they see a Clergy Gown.
Let them e'er they crack a Louse
Call for th' Orders of the House.
Let them with their Gosling Quills
Scrible senseless heads of Bills.
We may while they strain their Throats
Wipe our A── with their Votes.
Let ·Sr Ts Pendergs Sr Tom that rampant Ass
Stuff his Guts with Flax & Grass,
But before ye Priest he fleeces
Tear the Bible all to pieces.
At the Parsons, Tom, halloo Boy,
Worthy Offspring of a Shoe boy,
Footman, Traitor, vile Seducer,
Perjurd Rebel, brib'd Accuser;
Lay thy paltry priv\'·over·i\lege aside
Sprung from Papist & \del·a\ Regicide;
Fall a working like a Mole,
Raise your dirt about your Hole.
Come assist me, Muse obedient,
Let us try some new Expedient,
Shift the Scene for half an hour
Time & Place are in thy Power;
Thither, gentle Muse, conduct me,
I shall ask and you instruct me.
See! the Muse unbarrs the Gate,
Hark, the Monkeys how they Prate:
All the Gods who rule the Soul,
Styx, thro' Hell whose waters roll,
Let me be allowd to tell
What I heard in yonder Cell.
Near the Door an Entrance gapes
Crowded round with Antic Shapes,
Poverty & Grief & Care,
Causeless Ioy & true Despair,
Discord Periwiggd with Snakes,
See the dreadfull Stride she takes.
By this odious Crew beset
I began to rage & fret,
And resolvd to break their Pates
E'er we ent'red at the Gates,
Had not Clio in the Nick
Whisperd me, Let down your Stick,
What, said I, is this the Mad-house,
These, she answerd, are but Shadows,
Phantoms bodiless & vain,
Empty Visions of the Brain.
In the Porch Briareus stands
Shews a Bribe in all his hands,
Briareus the Secretary,
But we Mortals call him Cary,
When the Rogues their Country fleece
They may hope for Pence a piece.
Clio who had been so wise
To put on a Fools disguise,
To bespeak some Approbation
And be thought a near Relation;
When she two hundred Brutes,
All involvd in wild disputes
Roaring till their Lungs were spent
Privilege of Parliament,
Now a new misfortune feels,
Dreading to be laid by the heels,
Never durst a Muse before
Enter that Infernal Door.
Clio stiffled with the Smell
Into Spleen & Vapours fell
By the Stygian Steams that flew
From that dire infectious Crew;
Not the Stench of Lake Avernus
Coud have more offended her Nose;
Had she flown but o'er the Top
She must feel her Pinions drop
And by Exhalations dire
Tho' a Goddess must expire.
In a Fright she crept away;
Bravely I resolvd to stay.
When I saw the Keeper frown
Tipping him with half a Crown.
Now, said I, we are alone,
Name your Heroes one by one.
Who is that Hell-featurd Brawler\hole\
Is it Satan── no── tis Waller.
In what a Figure can a Bard dress
Iack the Grandson of Sr Hardress.
Honest Keeper drive him further,
In his Looks are Hell and Murther.
See the Scowling Visage drop
Iust as when he murtherd Throp\hole\
Keeper, shew me where to fix
On the ·Tigh\hole\. Puppy pair of Dicks.
By their Lanthorn Iaws & Leathern
You might swear they both are Bre\hole\
Dick Fitz-Baker. Dick the Playe\hole\
Old Acquaintance are you there\hole\
Dear Companions hug & Kiss
Toast old Glorious in your \hole\
Tie 'em, Keeper, in a teath\hole\
Let them starve & stink \hole\
Both are apt to be unr\hole\
Lash 'em daily, lash \?th\\hole\
Tho its hopeless to \hole\
Scorpion Rods per\hole\
Keeper, yon old Dotard smoak
Sweetly snoring in his Cloak,
Who is he── 'tis humdrum Wynne
Half incompassd by his Kin.
There observe the tribe of Bingham,
\hole\or he never fails to bring them,
\hole\d the base Apostate Vesey
\hole\ith Bishops scraps tho' fat & greazy;
\hole\hile he sleeps the whole debate
\hole\ey submissive round him wait,
\hole\Yet would gladly see the Hunks
In his Grave & search his Trunks)
See they gently twitch his Coat
Iust to yawn & give his Vote,
Always firm in his Vocation
For the Court against the Nation.
These are Allens Iack & Bob
\hole\ in evry wicked Iobb,
\hole\ \?B\rother to a queer
\hole\ick Brute they call a Peer.
\hole\ ive em better Quarter
\hole\ estor trod Mortar,
\hole\ boast his Fame
\hole\ t his name.
There sit Clements, Dylkes\──·over·,\& Carter
Who for Hell woud die a Martyr,
Such a Triplet coud you tell
Where to find on this side Hell,
Gallows Carter, Dylkes & Clements
Souse them in their own Excrements;
om.
om.
Every Mischief in their Hearts,
If they fail, tis want of Parts.
Bless us! Morgan, art thou there, man,
Bless mine Eyes, art thou the Chairman.
Chairman on yon damnd Committee,
Yet I look on thee with Pity.
Dreadfull sight! that learned Morgan
Metamorphosd to a Gorgon,
For thy horrid looks I own
Half convert me to a stone.
Hast thou been so long at School
Now to turn a Faction's Fool!
Alma Mater was thy Mother,
Evry young Divine thy Brother;
Thou, a disobedient \V·over·H\arl\e·over·o\t
Treat thy Mother like a Harlot.
Thou, ungratefull to thy Teachers
Who are all grown Reverend Preachers,
Morgan, woud it not surprize one,
Turn thy nourishment to Poison,
When you walk among your Books
They reproach you with their looks,
Bind them fast or from their Shelves
They will come & right themselves.
Homer, Plutarch, Virgil, Flaccus,
All in Arms prepare to back us.
Soon repent, or put to Slaughter
Ev'ry Greek & Roman Author.
Will you in your Faction's Phrase
Send the Clergy all to graze
And to make the Project pass
Leave 'em not a Blade of Grass.
How I want the hum'rous Hogart,
Thou I hear a pleasant Rogue art,
Were but you & I acquainted
Evry monster shoud be painted,
You shoud try your graving tools
On this odious groupe of Fools.
Draw the Beasts as I describe them,
From their Features while I gibe them.
Draw them like for I assure you
You will need no Caracatura.
Draw them so that we may trace
All the Soul in every Face.
Keeper, I must now retire
You have done what I desire,
But I feel my Spirits spent
With the noise── the sight── the scent.
Pray be patient, you shall find
Half the best are still behind.
You have hardly seen a score,
I can shew two hundred more.
Keeper, I have seen enough,
Taking then a pinch of Snuff
I concluded looking round them
May their God the Devil confound them.
